node.text:
@rob.mcmillan.wine, the wine industry expert and founder of SVB’s Wine Group, talks about how wineries adapted during the pandemic and how they can attract younger consumers.

#winespectator #wsstraighttalk #wine

node.text: The grape grower, CEO of Napa Valley Fumé and co-founder of the Napa Valley Cannabis Association discusses how #wine and #cannabis can be good neighbors.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator on August 03, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and text that says 'RIEDEL THE WINE GLASS COMPANY GRAPE VARIETAL SPECIFIC SL RIEDEL STEMLESS WINGS LET YOUR WINE TAKE FLIGHT GEORG RIEDEL OTH GENERATION MAXIMILIAN J. RIEDEL 11TH GENERATION'.

node.text: Riedel Crystal is a 265 year-old family owned company known for its creation and development of varietal-specific stemware. Georg and Maximilian Riedel are pleased to introduce their latest collection, SL Riedel Stemless Wings; the perfect compliment to the original stemmed Riedel Winewings series, redesigned to ensure they sit comfortable within the drinker’s hand. Click the link in bio to learn more. #sponsored

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator on August 02, 2021.

node.text:
Our first image for August’s #WSfeaturedphotographer series is of Ildewild Wines winemaker Sam Bilbro's grape-stained (and perhaps fatigued?) hand during the 2019 harvest.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Last month we featured the work of photographer Jimmy Hayes, who gave us images using the theme of ‘winery work’. With summer winding down here in the northern hemisphere, harvest is about to begin. So for August, our  #WSfeaturedphotographer Leigh-Ann Beverley was given the theme of ‘harvest work’.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Leigh-Ann grew up outside of Washington. D.C., in a house of guitars, cameras and records. She had her first epiphany with a camera at the age of eleven. Years later she wound up dragging a bag of wine samples around Charleston, telling the stories of producers from all over the world. After a nearly a decade working in the wine industry, she began to wonder how she might combine her childhood dream with her professional passion. This alchemy finally came to life in October of 2014 when she created her company Bona Fide Productions and she has been devoting her energy to visual storytelling through both still and moving images ever since.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Since switching to photography and video, Leigh-Ann’s travels have taken her to Germany, South America, France, California and more. We’ll be featuring her work throughout this month. We hope you enjoy her imagery as much as we do!⁠
⁠⁠
📸: @bonafideproductions⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #WSfeaturedphotographer #winephotography #harvestwork

node.text:
Nothing draws a crowd like a beautiful charcuterie board overflowing with fine cheeses, enticing meats, fruits, nuts, sweets and more. Wine Spectator's editors share 3 keys for constructing a winning cheese board, tips on how much you need, an easy hack for stunning salami rosettes and 4 wine-pairing recommendations!
.
.
.
.
#winespectator #wine #WSlifestyle #charcuterieboard

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator in Wine Spectator. May be an image of fruit.

node.text:
What wine grape do you think of when you see this?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠This grape originated in Southwest France, where it's also known as Côt; it is still the main grape in the area's top appellation, Cahors. It was once a significant blending partner in Bordeaux's reds, but has largely fallen out of favor there. Farther north in France, it has a presence in the Loire Valley. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Today it's become most associated with Argentina, where it has become that country's signature red grape. It's also grown in other New World regions, including California, Chile and Australia.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Click the linkin.bio for more on Malbec and our entire Know Your Grapes library.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
. ⁠⁠
📸: Andrew Purcell⁠⁠
⁠⁠
#WineSpectator #wine #WSeducate #Malbec #KnowYourGrapes #winegrapes #tastingnotes

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator on July 30, 2021. May be an image of one or more people.

node.text:
Don't you appreciate when someone tops off your glass of wine?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Well, before that can happen, the winemaker has to make sure the barrels get topped off too. As a wine ages in barrel, a small amount evaporates (known as the "angels' share"). Keeping the wine topped up prevents oxidation from creeping in. It's one of the many aspects of winery work that goes on quietly behind the scenes.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Jimmy Hayes, our #WSfeaturedphotographer for July, captured this shot of cellarmaster Alberto Nuño-Sanchez topping up Chardonnay barrels in the cellars of Kistler Vineyards.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Be sure to check out Hayes' book of photography, "Veritas" which releases in September via @CameronBooks and @AbramsBooks.⁠ Part of the proceeds will be sent directly to the Napa Valley Farmworker Foundation and the Sonoma Grape Growers Foundation, organizations that fund social and professional programs benefitting Napa and Sonoma County vineyard workers and their families. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
📸: @toomanyjimmys⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #WSfeaturedphotographer #winephotography #winerywork

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator on July 29, 2021. May be an image of bottle.

node.text: In 1985, family Esteban Martin decided to purchase 150 hectares of vineyards on the best land in the Cariñena PDO region. He acquired new plots of land year after year, before deciding to build his own winery in 2003. Today they have grown to 400 hectares of vineyards and boast state-of-the-art facilities and technology. However, they have not lost sight of the importance of tradition, know-how and responsibility. The day-to-day operations at the winery now involve three generations of the family, whose main values are quality, excellence and innovation, environmental sustainability and a love for the product and the land. Click the linkin.bio to learn more! #sponsored

node.text:
Nearly 30 years have passed since the end of apartheid, and in that time South Africa’s wine producers have established an identity unlike anywhere else. They have fine-tuned their viticulture and winemaking practices to align with local conditions, vines and soils, and the results impress on many fronts. Consumers can enjoy high quality bottlings from different grape varieties, at generally wallet-friendly prices and in an array of styles, including reds and whites, sparklers and sweeties.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Senior Editor @napjuswine pens this year's annual report on the Cape's wines, covering more than 250 new releases from nearly 75 different producers representing 20 different varietals, including blue-chips such as Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, Chenin Blanc, Chardonnay and Sauvignon Blanc.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Click the linkin.bio for the full report, so you can get all the info you need to pick out some lekker juice...!⁠⁠
⁠⁠.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
. ⁠⁠
⁠#winespectator #wine #SouthAfrica #winewednesday⁠⁠

node.text:
Our weekly Tasting Highlights offer a selection of wine reviews fresh out of the tasting room, giving a sneak peek of our editors’ most recent scores and notes to WineSpectator.com members.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
With summer in full swing, that means it's the peak of rosé season...and we've got you covered with this batch of notes featuring reviews on new rosés from Provence. Included are the latest releases from producers such as Château Pradeaux, Château Vannières, La Fête du Rosé, Hecht & Bannier, Château d'Esclans’ (as in Whispering Angel) and Jolie-Pitt & Perrin’s Miraval...⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Click the linkin.bio for the full scoop. And if you're not subscribing to our website already, maybe now's the time!⁠⁠
⁠⁠.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
. ⁠⁠
📸: @Lisic Marijan ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #Provence #rosé #roséallday⁠⁠
#tastingnotes

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator in Napa Valley Wine Country with @mayadv, and @dallavallevineyards. May be an image of 1 person, drink and indoor.

node.text:
Many wines are blends, either of different varietals or different pieces of terroir. ⁠Mixing varying percentages of different varietals or terroirs can result in very different expressions of the end wine. So whichever way you look at it, blending is a critical part of the winemaking process.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Here, winemaker Maya Dalla Valle is working on the blends of her wines. It's part of our month-long series entitled 'winery work' featuring behind-the-scenes images captured by Jimmy Hayes, our #WSfeaturedphotographer for July.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Be sure to check out Hayes' book of photography, "Veritas" which releases in September via @CameronBooks and @AbramsBooks.⁠ Part of the proceeds will be sent directly to the Napa Valley Farmworker Foundation and the Sonoma Grape Growers Foundation, organizations that fund social and professional programs benefitting Napa and Sonoma County vineyard workers and their families. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Click the link.bio for more.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
📸: @toomanyjimmys⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #WSfeaturedphotographer #winephotography #winerywork

node.text:
What wine grape do you think of when you see this?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
This white grape originated in France's Loire Valley, likely in the Anjou subregion, which today makes the world's most acclaimed versions...⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The grape's frontiers have expanded, to South Africa, where it’s that country's most widely planted white grape, as well as to some regions in the U.S., most notably California.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
It's Chenin Blanc, an early-budding, mid-ripening grape that grows successfully in varied soil types, including silex, schist, sand and clay. It's also made in a range of styles and sweetness levels.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Click the linkin.bio for more on Chenin Blanc and our entire #KnowYourGrapes library.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
. ⁠⁠
📸: Andrew Purcell⁠⁠
⁠⁠
#WineSpectator #wine #WSeducate #CheninBlanc #CheninCheninChenin #KnowYourGrapes #winegrapes #tastingnotes ⁠⁠

node.text:
Are you cutting back on wine to cut calories? Maybe you shouldn't. As one food scientist pointed out during a health webinar last month, moderate wine intake during meals may help boost metabolism and support weight loss.⁠
⁠
Dr. Rosa Lamuela-Raventos, associate professor of nutrition and food science at the University of Barcelona and member of the Spanish Biomedical Research Centre in Physiopathology of Obesity and Nutrition, presented her support for moderate wine consumption at “Wine and Weight Management: Is It Possible?” a virtual event hosted by Wine in Moderation, a wine-focused corporate social responsibility program.⁠
⁠
Tap linkin.bio for the full story…⁠
⁠
📸: @alinatyulyu⁠
.⁠
.⁠
.⁠
.⁠
#winespectator #wine #winehealth #healthyliving #WSlifestyle⁠
